threads.com:
I've been talking regularly with this girl for quite some time now. I reached the point where we call each other on a daily basis and watch the series we are into. We are watching Gintama now, her choice. We like the same things, and she truly enjoys showing me stuff I don't know. She's beautiful, and I admire her a lot, I really want to take the next step but I don't know how to do it.

She's really, really socially akward, I went to her place the other day and she could barely make eye contact with me. She didn't show any signs of disgust though, on the contrary, she was quite excited for me to be there. I'm 75% sure she has some type of autism, Asperger most likely, but I'm not entirely sure yet and honestly don't really care.

I know for a fact that I'm her most recent IRL friend in a long time, maybe since she finished school 5 years ago (we went to the same school but never talked because of the age difference). I believe she's this nice with me because she doesn't remember the last time she could talk about anything she likes with another person who is not her mother or her sister. I enjoy being her friend, but I have the fear that one day It will be too late for me to confess what I feel. I want to respect her boundaries, but I don't know how much time I can keep being just her friend.

Kind of a faggot thread, I know, but I'm asking for legit advice. I'm a 19yo dumbass with no experience in love, and she's basically the same thing + 2 years of no human interaction.

threads.com:
how does one deal with the sudden and soul-crushing realization that one is limited by who they are?

there's intrinsic personality traits and deep psychological undercurrents that limit me to what i can achieve and become.

after a mindblowing mushroom trip, i lived a period of my life under an extremely positive but misguided idea that me and everybody else had unlimited potential in them. that if people could just see what they're capable of they could do anything they wanted. that was a manic and very good little period in my life, but now that i ventured more into the world, and with some time and a whole lot of neurosis caused by the stresses of the real world, i've changed my point of view: i believe i am deeply deeply limited to what i can become.

my deep vulnerability to stress, i can't handle too much stress or i shut down, i tried to work on this for years, but no matter how many stressful situations i'm in i never seem to get any better, it's like baked-in thing that i won't ever change. or the fact that my relationship to other people is flawed in some deep psychological way, that i either trust people too much or don't trust any of them at all, i've tried changing this too, but it doesn't seem to go away. or my sensitivity to the real world and all its happenings. all these bedrock principles that make me who i am, i feel i will never be able to change, no matter how many mushroom trips or self-reflection or exposure therapy i apply. these, and other foundational aspects, make me who i am and limit me in my growth.

maybe it's better to believe that i CAN change and completely conquer some of these aspects, but the more i try, the more i see that there are unshakeable rules to my character. does anybody sort of relate to what i'm saying? and what would be the solution? try to live with a positive all-conquering attitude that will inevitably fall down again, or succumb to your rules? i think it's better to fight against them, but it's hard sometimes

As a minority you already are very lucky and should embrace that. Whatever your culture is, learn about it and hang out with people from it.

Work/career wise:

The moment you get a leg up in some field simply by BEING there and having an educated opinion you're valued.Forget about talent, work hard and build good habits.

We are social animals and should want to find a community / collective that supports us.

Lots of jewishness in the replies, so take heed that the sorts of people who are replying do not have your interests in mind.

First of all I'm compelled to congratulate you. That's almost four months. That's better than I've ever done. You've put together a stretch that could have others asking you for advice.

When temptations come, they're temporary. Can you attach a different result to this particular stimulus? For example, when the urge strikes, that's a time to go...[brew coffee][cold shower][1km quick jog][30 pushups][plow girlfriend][take dog for brisk walk] etc.

The recent habit I successfully defeated was sugar addiction, and I realized that the nature of my cravings was that they were strong but only really comprised like 10-15 minutes of a day, so if I thought of that as analogous to exercise, it was a temporary discomfort to endure for a long term gain. Maybe you can use this philosophy. Good luck and good job so far.

So create a narrative around that that gives you some fire when the temptations come.

last_replies.com:
>>27781396
Medical help to quit alcohol:

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind and body create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. You can know something is bad and decide to quit, but you still go up against the basic urges/cravings. The rational mind is losing to basic, powerful impulses. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center".

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.
